DBSC Global Network Infrastructure
A comprehensive design and simulation of a secure, scalable, and resilient network infrastructure for the Digital Banking Service Company (DBSC). This project establishes a robust global network connecting the headquarters in Amman with six international branches, ensuring seamless communication, data sharing, and access to critical services.

The entire network was designed, implemented, and tested using Cisco Packet Tracer.

![Network Topology](data:image/png;base64,)

Key Features
Global WAN Connectivity: Connects the Amman HQ Data Center to branches in Istanbul, Riyadh, Dubai, London, Beirut, and Cairo.

Dynamic Routing: Implemented OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) for efficient and scalable routing between all sites.

Comprehensive Network Services: Centralized servers providing essential services:

DHCP: Automated IP configuration for all clients.

DNS: Resolving human-readable domain names (eis.DBSC.com.jo) to IP addresses.

HTTP/HTTPS: Secure access to the company's internal web portal.

Email (SMTP/POP3): Fully functional internal email system.

FTP: Secure file sharing and transfer capabilities.

Hierarchical Network Design: A logical combination of WAN and Star topologies to ensure both inter-site connectivity and intra-site reliability.

Security: Core security principles are applied, including router access control (passwords) and segregation of network traffic.

Detailed IP Schema: A meticulously planned VLSM (Variable Length Subnet Mask) based on the 172.20.0.0/16 address space to ensure efficient IP address allocation and scalability for future growth.

Network Architecture
The network is built on a robust hub-and-spoke model, with the Amman Headquarters acting as the central hub.

WAN Topology
The core of the network is a Wide Area Network (WAN) that interconnects all seven international offices. OSPF is used as the routing protocol to automatically manage the best paths for data traffic between locations, providing both efficiency and redundancy.

LAN Topology
Each individual office, including the headquarters, is designed using an Extended Star Topology.

A central switch on each floor connects end-user devices (PCs, Laptops, Printers).

This design simplifies management, isolates failures, and allows for easy scalability within each office.

Wireless access is provided via access points, allowing for secure mobility for laptops and other portable devices.

[You can add a screenshot of a single branch LAN design here]
![Branch LAN Topology](path/to/your/lan_screenshot.png)

Services & Protocols
The network supports a full range of enterprise-level services hosted in the Amman Data Center.

Service

Protocol(s)

Port(s)

Purpose

Web Portal

HTTP / HTTPS

80 / 443

Provides secure access to the internal company system.

Domain Name System

DNS

53

Translates eis.DBSC.com.jo to its IP for easy access.

Dynamic IPs

DHCP

67 / 68

Automatically assigns IP addresses to all network devices.

Email

SMTP / POP3

587 / 110

Manages the sending and receiving of all internal emails.

File Sharing

FTP

445

Allows employees to securely share and manage files.

Getting Started
To explore this network simulation, you will need Cisco Packet Tracer (version 8.0 or higher is recommended).

Download the Project:

Clone this repository or download the .pkt file.

Open in Packet Tracer:

Launch Cisco Packet Tracer.

Open the DBSC_Network.pkt file.

Explore and Test:

The network is fully configured and operational. You can enter Simulation Mode to visualize data packet flow.

Run tests from any PC's Command Prompt:

Ping a server in the Data Center from a branch office PC:

ping 172.20.2.2

Look up the company's web server using DNS:

nslookup eis.DBSC.com.jo

Access the web portal by opening the Web Browser on any PC and navigating to https://eis.DBSC.com.jo.

Test the FTP and Email clients available on the PCs.
